'Ethics',is also known as 'moral philosophy', the discipline concerned with what is morally good and bad, right and wrong. The word is also applied to any system or theory of moral values or principles.The term comes from the Greek word [[ethos]], which means "character". Ethics is a complement to [[Aesthetics]] in the philosophy field of [[Axiology]]. In philosophy, ethics studies the moral behavior in humans and how one should act. When we expand the word “philosophy”, it comes out with different solutions or visions. Moreover, it is very deeply and it stimulates the mind of people to think critically and logically. As a short way, it makes someone to become a good thinker or philosopher. The philosophers are shared their insights and tried to pop up with different ideas or vision from different point of views.
−
Ethics may be divided into four major areas of study:<ref name="iep.utm.edu"/>
  −
* [[Meta-ethics]], about the theoretical meaning and reference of moral propositions and how their [[truth value]]s (if any) may be determined;
  −
* [[Normative ethics]], about the practical means of determining a moral course of action;
  −
* [[Applied ethics]], about how moral outcomes can be achieved in specific situations;
  −
* [[Descriptive ethics]], also known as comparative ethics, is the study of people's beliefs about morality;
      −
Ethics seeks to resolve questions dealing with human morality—concepts such as [[good and evil]], [[right and wrong]], [[virtue]] and [[vice]], [[justice]] and [[crime]].
       
== Defining ethics ==
 
== Defining ethics ==
−
According to Tomas Paul and Linda Elder of the [[Foundation for Critical Thinking]], "most people confuse ethics with behaving in accordance with social conventions, religious beliefs and the law", and don't treat ethics as a stand-alone concept.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite book |title= The Miniature Guide to Understanding the Foundations of Ethical Reasoning|edition= |last1= Paul|first1= Richard|last2= Elder|first2= Linda|year= 2006|publisher= Foundation for Critical Thinking Free Press|location= United States|isbn= 0-944583-17-2|page= np}}</ref> Paul and Elder define ethics as "a set of concepts and principles that guide us in determining what behavior helps or harms sentient creatures".<ref name="ReferenceA"/> The ''[[Cambridge Dictionary of Philosophy]]'' states that the word ethics is "commonly used interchangeably with 'morality' ... and sometimes it is used more narrowly to mean the moral principles of a particular tradition, group or individual."<ref>John Deigh in Robert Audi (ed), ''The Cambridge Dictionary of Philosophy'', 1995.</ref>
